original.problem:
## Task 31/61

To convert rotational movements into linear movements, there are various possibilities. In machine tools, the cross-slide (construction principle see first figure) and the oscillating crank-slide (construction principle see second figure) are frequently used.

The radius $r$ of the rotational movement is the distance from the pivot point $M$ to the center of the bolt $B$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-028.jpg?height=517&width=763&top_left_y=1518&top_left_x=949)

a) The displacement $s$ of the oscillating machine part (tool or workpiece) as a function of the angle of rotation $\varphi$ is to be specified, and the function $s=f(\varphi)$ is to be represented in a Cartesian coordinate system with $r=1$, $a=0.5$, and $l=3$. What is the essential difference in the movement of the oscillating machine part between the two drive types?

b) For the cross-slide, the velocity $v=v(t)$ and the acceleration $b=b(t)$ of the oscillating machine part are to be determined; the angular velocity $\omega$ is constant: $\omega=\frac{\varphi}{t}=$ constant.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-029.jpg?height=545&width=811&top_left_y=293&top_left_x=631)

c) What is the absolute extreme value of the acceleration for the cross-slide? What diameter $d$ must the bolt $B$ have at a minimum if $\tau$ is the shear strength of the bolt material and $m$ is the mass of the oscillating machine part?

The relationship $\tau=\frac{P}{F}$ applies, where $F$ is the cross-sectional area of the material and $P$ is the force required to shear (mutual displacement of two "adjacent" cross-sections). Friction is to be neglected.

d) For the oscillating crank-slide, the approximate course of the velocity-time function and the acceleration-time function is to be read from the graphical representation of the displacement-time function and graphically represented. Here, too, $\omega=\frac{\varphi}{t}=$ constant applies.

e) For which types of machines do these two drive types come into question primarily due to their properties?
original.solution:
a) Crosshead: It is (see figure) $s=MS$. If the angle of rotation $\varphi$ is the angle that the crank $MB=r$ sweeps out in a clockwise direction from MO, then

$$
\frac{MS}{r} = \frac{s}{r} = \cos \left(90^{\circ} - \varphi\right)
$$

Since $\cos \left(90^{\circ} - \varphi\right) = \sin \varphi$, it follows that $\frac{s}{r} = \sin \varphi$ and thus $s = r \sin \varphi$.

Graphical representation for $r=2$ and $r=1$:

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-029.jpg?height=525&width=808&top_left_y=1865&top_left_x=630)

Swinging Crank: If the angle of rotation $\varphi$ is the angle that the crank $MB=r$ sweeps out in a clockwise direction from $MO$ (figure), and the swing angle $\psi$ is the angle between $PS$ and $PO$ (also measured in a clockwise direction), then $\frac{OS}{PO} = \frac{s}{l} = \tan \psi$ and thus $s = l \tan \psi$. Now, it follows that

$$
\tan \psi = \frac{TB}{PT} = \frac{TB}{PQ + QM + MT} = \frac{TB}{a + r + MT}
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-030.jpg?height=471&width=719&top_left_y=221&top_left_x=660)

Thus, the desired function is: $s = l \cdot \frac{\sin \varphi}{\frac{a}{r} + 1 + \cos \varphi}$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-030.jpg?height=551&width=642&top_left_y=792&top_left_x=707)

Graphical representation for $r=1, a=0.5, l=3$: In the crosshead, the machine part oscillates harmonically, whereas in the swinging crank, it does not. In the crosshead, the forward and return strokes take the same amount of time, while in the swinging crank, the forward stroke is slow and the return stroke is fast.

b) The velocity $v=v(t)$ is obtained by differentiating the path with respect to time:

$$
v = v(t) = \frac{ds(t)}{dt} = \frac{d(r \sin \varphi)}{dt} = \frac{d(r \sin (\omega t))}{dt}
$$

By the chain rule, it follows that

$$
\frac{d(r \sin (\omega t))}{dt} = \frac{d(r \sin \varphi)}{d\varphi} \cdot \frac{d(\omega t)}{dt} = \omega r \cos (\omega t) = \omega r \cos \varphi
$$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-030.jpg?height=349&width=628&top_left_y=1953&top_left_x=720)

The acceleration $b=b(t)$ is the derivative of the velocity with respect to time. Again, by the chain rule, $b = -\omega^2 r \sin (\omega t) = -\omega^2 r \sin \varphi$.

c) The extreme values of $b=b(t)$ occur at the zeros of the first derivative of $b$, where the second derivative is non-zero: $\frac{db(t)}{dt} = -\omega^3 r \cos (\omega t) = -\omega^3 r \cos \varphi$.

From $-\omega^3 r \cos \varphi = 0$, it follows that $\cos \varphi = 0$. This is the case for $\varphi = 90^{\circ} + k \cdot 180^{\circ}, k = 0; 1; 2; 3; \ldots$.

Now, $\frac{d^2 b(t)}{dt} = \omega^4 r \sin \varphi$.

For $\varphi = 90^{\circ} + (2k + 1) \cdot 180^{\circ}, k = 0; 1; 2; 3; \ldots$, $\sin \varphi = -1$, so there are maximum values. For $\varphi = 90^{\circ} + 2k \cdot 180^{\circ}, k = 0; 1; 2; 3; \ldots$, there are minimum values. In each case, however, $|b_{\text{extrem}}| = \omega^2 r$. From the fundamental law of dynamics $P = m b$, for the extreme values of $b: |P_{\text{extrem}}| = m |b_{\text{extrem}}| = m \omega^2 r$.

Further, at the bolt breakage $P = \tau F$. Setting $P > |P_{\text{extrem}}|$, it follows that $\tau F > m \omega^2 r$, and thus, since $F = \frac{d^2}{4} \pi$, also $\frac{d^2}{4} \pi \tau > m \omega^2 r$.

From this, the diameter $d$ is calculated as

$$
d \geq 2 \omega \sqrt{\frac{m r}{\pi \tau}}
$$

d) In the range $0^{\circ} \leq \varphi \leq 105^{\circ}$, the path-time function increases almost linearly, so the velocity-time function is approximately constant in this interval, greater than zero. From $\varphi \approx 105^{\circ}$ to $\varphi \approx 133^{\circ}$, the velocity decreases to zero (maximum path), and from $\varphi \approx 133^{\circ}$ to $\varphi \approx 227^{\circ}$, it becomes negative, with its smallest value apparently between $\varphi \approx 165^{\circ}$ and $\varphi \approx 195^{\circ}$; in this interval, it is constant, its absolute value about five times the value between $0^{\circ}$ and $105^{\circ}$.

From $\varphi \approx 227^{\circ}$, the velocity becomes positive again, and from $\varphi \approx 255^{\circ}$, it remains approximately constant, the same size as between $0^{\circ}$ and $105^{\circ}$. The curve of the velocity $v$ will therefore roughly correspond to the previous figure.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_06_1d2be4837fb839c2b31dg-031.jpg?height=394&width=696&top_left_y=1002&top_left_x=677)

The curve of the acceleration is shown in the upper figure.

e) Crossheads are primarily used in machines where both the forward stroke and the return stroke are working strokes (e.g., machine files and machine saws).

Swinging cranks, on the other hand, are mainly used in machines that only perform work during the forward stroke and run idle during the return stroke (e.g., long planing machines). The faster return stroke reduces the idle time and thus better utilizes the machine. Additionally, the constant velocity during the working stroke is advantageous.
